Award.AwardTitle: CC-NIE Network Infrastructure: Enabling Data-Intensive Research at the University of Connecticut Through Science DMZ

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Award.AbstractNarration:
The goal of this project is to improve the network infrastructure at the University of Connecticut (UConn), in both the main campus at Storrs and the Health Center at Farmington, to enable data-intensive research. Specifically, the project (1) constructs a Science DMZ at the Storrs campus that provides an aggregate access bandwidth of 100Gbps to its regional network provider, (2) re-architects the current Science DMZ at the Farmington campus and increases its access bandwidth from 2Gbps to 100Gbps, and (3) establishes a 40Gbps layer-2 connection between the Storrs and Farmington campuses dedicated to scientific traffic between these two campuses.

Intellectual Merit: The project is expected to significantly increase data transfer rate to specific projects in physics, geography, statistics, biology, bioinformatics, quantitative cell biology and simulations, and computational genomics, directly benefiting research in a wide range of disciplines. The enhanced network connectivity will also make an impact on closely interlinking the two campuses, fostering multidisciplinary research that can lead to scientific breakthroughs.

Broader Impacts: The project will enhance the capabilities of researchers to host data and share data with researchers in other institutions, which can benefit a larger community of researchers. The proposed infrastructure will also facilitate our current GENI educational activities by providing a platform for computer networking courses and training programs. The researchers participating in the project will continue their current practice of involving minority and underrepresented students in research, and will disseminate their research outcomes to the scientific communities through journal and conference publications.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The goal of this joint project involving two linked awards was to design and deploy a new network infrastructure at the University of Connecticut at the main campus in Storrs and the Health Center campus in Farmington that enables data-intensive research.  This network connectivity facilitates cross-campus use of UConn?s two High Performance Computing (HPC) facilities located in Storrs and Farmington, respectively. Over the duration of the project, as part of the UConn Health award in Farmington, we have installed a 100Gbps Internet connection, which is separate from, and has a tenfold higher capacity then the medical center connection.  It serves research performed using the HPC facility located in the dedicated datacenter at the Cell and Genome Science building in Farmington, which is now accessible to faculty, staff and students form all campuses through a re-architected Science DMZ allowing both non-firewalled access for research data transfers, and restricted access for research involving private health information that needs to meet HIPAA compliance.

Additionally, we have deployed specific network connections to support a large capacity geo-distributed data storage system across three datacenters many miles apart. This rapidly growing scalable system works like an on-premise cloud storage and has proven to be crucial to allow UConn researchers and their external collaborators to exchange large datasets and archive data for future use. We have developed solutions to resolve performance issues that have been identified through the benchmarking efforts and included outreach activities to undergraduate and graduate students on data-intensive research and technologies to facilitate such research; these are described on the website of the other linked award at http://nlab.engr.uconn.edu/currentprojects_cc-nie_ni.html.

The new network capabilities of the infrastructure that was deployed as a resulted of this project will benefit for years to come research activities in a wide range of disciplines including physics, engineering, bioinformatics, quantitative cell biology, and computational genomics.
